ygData.subject: Re: map navigation

My suggestion would be to use HyperNEAT to input the whole map (with enemie=
s) as an input field.  Then the output field can be another field of the sa=
me dimension where HyperNEAT highlights where it thinks the best hiding pla=
ce is.  It will work best if it is trained for specific maps.  That is, it =
would not generalize to another map than the one on which it was trained.

=
I think this is a good problem for HyperNEAT because it can deal with the h=
igh input dimensionality, and it can also output in high-dimensionality, i.=
e. by highlighting where it thinks a good location to hide is on the map.

=
For NEAT it would be harder to deal with the dimensionality of inputs and o=
utputs.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "shanemcdonaldryan" <shanemcdona=
ldryan@...> wrote:
>
> I am implementing a bot (AI for a video game). I am =
trying to evolve a behaviour with NEAT for choosing a point on a map to nav=
igate too.
> 
> I am using the routing algorithm A* to create the path betw=
een points.
> 
> The algorithm will have to (ideally) choose the best point=
 to run too and hide at from a set of points it has encountered before.
> 
=
> The set of possible navigable points should grow as the AI bot encounters=
 them.
> 
> The bot will navigate for different reasons. But right now the =
reason will be to avoid enemy players.
> 
> Any suggestions on how to struc=
ture the inputs and fitness function?
> 
> To summarize I want the neural n=
et to choose the best place to hide in a map. The A* algorithm will then cr=
eate the path between this point and the bots current position.
> 
> Thanks=
 for any suggestions,
> 
> Shane
>
